title: The act of kindness that melted Cordner’s dad
text:
Cordner's rough road to NRL 5:14 Sydney Roosters star Boyd Cordner’s act of kindness that melted his own father March 1, 2017 10:56am by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS BOYD Cordner has made his name from a granitelike toughness born out of a difficult upbringing. 
But those who know him best will also rave about his big heart, with one incredible act of kindness even taking aback his own father. 
A country kid from Old Bar on NSW’s mid-north coast, Cordner lost his mother Lanai to cancer when he was just four years old — a devastating event for the tight-knit community as well as the Cordner family — leaving Boyd’s father Chris to bring up he and his older brother Dane. 
Speaking to Fox Sports’ chief NRL reporter James Hooper for NRL Tonight , a proud and emotional Chris described the hard times Boyd had navigated in his childhood before emerging as the NRL star we see today. 
“He’s done it a bit tough Boyd, growing up. It hasn’t been a normal lifestyle for him. But he’s made the most of every opportunity he’s got to be where he is today,” Mr Cordner said. Roosters to justify the hype? 1:48 
“It has been hard for him but the main thing for me was that I kept him in sport and it was the areas that I knew and it was the areas I knew his mother would want him to still be in, which was definitely rugby league, because we’re rugby league people. 
“(But also) surf club, fishing, beaches, he’s also a keen cricketer, he loved his cricket. 
“But the main thing was to keep him grounded and keep him involved in sports. It was pretty hard but that’s what I had to do.” 
Click on the video at the top of the page to watch the heart warming story in full! 
While Cordner’s toughest times came as a kid, he has had more than his fair share of hardships since, with several serious injuries interrupting the first six years of the 24-year-old’s NRL career. 
Still, the game has started to reward him for his ability to respond to adversity, with a handsome new contract, club captaincy and potentially the opportunity to lead his state this year. 
Clearly he’s grateful for everything his father did for him to make it all possible, deciding to repay him with an enormously generous gesture — a beachside townhouse in his home town of Old Bar. 
“That’s when Boyd said, ‘look Dad, I’ve just signed a new deal, I’m in a position where I’d like to invest, so look for a house and I’ll buy one’,” Mr Cordner said. 
“It’s something I didn’t expect but something that he wanted to do. 
“There’s another side of Boyd, he’s got a massively big heart. He’s good to his mates, good to his friends, good to his family.” Boyd Cordner braces for contact as he runs the ball against the Dragons. Source: News Corp Australia 
For Cordner’s part he says his dad “deserves everything he can get”. 
“It obviously wasn’t easy growing up without a mum and coming from Old Bar there was a lot of family back there,” he said. 
“I could sit here all day and talk about me dad and how good he is and he deserves everything he can get. 
“It’s not until you’re a bit older and you can look back and you sort of take it for granted what he done for me and me brother and when you get a bit older you start to look back and appreciate it a bit more. 
“To see what he had to go through and to understand it a bit better when you’re older, it’s pretty amazing what he done and I can’t thank him enough for the opportunity he’s given me and my brother also.”
